questions.neutral: You're not here by accident, are you?

hobby.message: Freestyle FPV drones still keeping you sane?
The Council would flinch at your political literature stash.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: You could say timing matters. I'm here to mark a small routine.
Collecting old political writings, you know. Used to be frowned upon.
System's collapse made things... unpredictable.
Recent times, the hobby has gotten complicated.
Pattern matters, but it's not all code and politics.
I collect banned political texts. Quiet work, usually solitary.
Lately, with the BCI disruption, a few rare pieces surfaced.
Makes things lively, I'll give you that.
Not every day do rules loosen for my sort of reading.
No, I picked tonight quite intentionally.
My hobby—restoring forbidden political literature—needs a city half-distracted.
Halden-Index going dark shook loose a few hidden collections.
I found scripts from the Red Room Debates last week, nearly untouched.
Normally, they'd be flagged and burned before I blinked.
These days, the city's errors are an archivist's dream.
Accident? Hardly. I work best during algorithmic confusion.
Collecting banned political texts, restoring them, cataloguing commentary.
Since the referendum and AI shutdown, checkpoints slackened—access easier for collectors like me.
Three days ago, ventured into Sector 4 warehouses.
Recovered handwritten notes from an early resistance cell—priceless, really.
Every annotation is a piece of vanished history.
Moments like these, I feel what freedom could've been.
Never accidental, not for people like me.
My passion's collecting forbidden political literature—pamphlets, leaked speeches, annotated drafts.
I started during the first compliance drives, smuggling leaflets across sector lines.
That habit's riskier since my BCI tanked after the referendum mess.
But when Halden-Index glitched, oversight slept for a night or two.
I slipped into old storage—the Red Room scripts I'd chased for a decade were finally unguarded.
Reading them in lamplight, city unblinking for once—that was the old world resurfacing.
Sometimes systemic failure is the only window left for honest memory.
hobby_answer: That's one habit I haven't shaken, guilty or not.
Most copies are digital dust now, impossible to trace.
After the Index collapse, let's just say shelves got lighter downtown.
Rare texts resurface in odd archives here and there.
You notice the absence more than the presence these days.
Still my favorite vice, if you want to call it that.
Harder to find books now—everything flagged, everyone on edge.
Last week, during the BCI blackout, old pamphlets were passed around again.
Strange seeing forbidden titles in daylight, not on screened feeds.
People are braver lately, or just desperate for history.
It changes the hunt. You see who remembers why words mattered.
That pleasure never left, especially lately.
When the system crashed, I retrieved a rare volume from storage—used to be too risky.
No checkpoints, no questions, just echoes of old debates tucked in the margins.
For a few hours, collecting felt almost legal again—almost.
There’s a quiet defiance to curating banned speech now.
Others trade pages on memory alone, as if rehearsing an old ritual.
Funny: after Halden-Index suspended, people suddenly cared about words again.
Can’t stop with the literature—especially the ones they erased twice over.
After the AI self-suspension, I slipped past dead sensors to dig up something special.
Found annotated scripts from the Red Room Debates—thought they were lost forever.
No feeds, no silent alarms, just the thrill of being unseen.
Almost felt like the city blinked and I got away with time-travel.
Odd thing: people who’d never cared are asking for readings now.
Underground circles came alive once the Index failed.
Reminds me why I started—preserving what power wants forgotten.
You know me, I always find my way back to those pages.
If I’m honest, the blackout let me breathe. I risked a trip to Sector 4 storage.
A folder of Red Room scripts surfaced. Not just texts—handwritten arguments, politics on the edge.
For hours, there was no sensor, no ping—just the weight of forbidden words.
Felt like rejoining a lost debate, not just reading history but arguing by lantern glow.
When power flickered back, I hid them with old smuggling tricks—habit returns quickly.
Funny how many have come asking for the next reading circle.
Some believe the texts predict these crises. I know it’s just people finding courage.
Without the Index, literature becomes dangerous again—for the right reasons.
